title: 107_s2855
content:
The Medicare Beneficiary Assistance Improvement Act of 2002 includes provisions such as renaming the program to eliminate confusion, expanding SLMB eligibility income level, eliminating barriers to enrollment, removing the asset test, improving assistance with out-of-pocket costs, enhancing program information and coordination, and providing notices to certain new Medicare beneficiaries. The Medicare Beneficiary Assistance Improvement Act of 2002 renames the program to "Medicare Savings Programs" to eliminate confusion. It also expands SLMB eligibility income level to 135 percent of poverty. The Medicare Beneficiary Assistance Improvement Act of 2002 expands SLMB eligibility income level to 135 percent of poverty and makes amendments to the Social Security Act regarding Medicaid provisions. The Medicare Beneficiary Assistance Improvement Act of 2002 expands SLMB eligibility income level to 135 percent of poverty and amends the Social Security Act to include medical assistance for Medicare cost-sharing starting in January 2003. The Medicare Beneficiary Assistance Improvement Act of 2002 expands SLMB eligibility income level to 135 percent of poverty and includes medical assistance for Medicare cost-sharing starting in January 2003. SEC. 4. ELIMINATING BARRIERS TO ENROLLMENT. The Medicare Beneficiary Assistance Improvement Act of 2002 expands SLMB eligibility income level to 135 percent of poverty and includes medical assistance for Medicare cost-sharing. Amendments to the Social Security Act allow SSI recipients in certain states to be deemed qualified Medicare beneficiaries. Self-certification of income is also introduced for eligibility determination. The State shall allow individuals to qualify based on self-certifications of income without additional documentation. Individuals deemed qualified Medicare beneficiaries or eligible for benefits under section 1902(a)(10)(E)(iii) will be automatically reenrolled without needing to reapply unless they notify the State of changes in eligibility conditions. The State allows individuals to apply for qualified Medicare beneficiary status or benefits under section 1902(a)(10)(E)(iii) using a simplified application process, which can be done over the phone or by mail without the need for an in-person interview. The Commissioner of Social Security will provide enrollment and information at local Social Security offices for Medicare cost-sharing benefits for qualified individuals and notify them orally and in writing about the availability of these benefits. Amendments are made to sections of the Act regarding the outstationing of State Eligibility Workers at SSA Field Offices for medical assistance applications. Amendments are made to sections of the Act regarding the outstationing of State Eligibility Workers at SSA Field Offices for medical assistance applications, which include field offices of the Social Security Administration. Amendments are made to eliminate the asset test for eligibility determinations for Medicare cost-sharing, effective January 1, 2003. Additionally, improvements are made to assistance with out-of-pocket costs. Amendments to the Social Security Act include eliminating estate recovery provisions and providing for 3-month retroactive eligibility for medical assistance. Section 1848(g)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to address retroactive eligibility for medical assistance, ensuring claims are resubmitted and re-processed accordingly. Improving program information and coordination with state, local, and other partners. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Commissioner of Social Security will conduct a Data Match Demonstration Project to exchange information between various agencies to identify individuals eligible for Medicare or medical assistance. The Data Match Demonstration Project aims to identify individuals eligible for medical assistance under the Social Security Act. Information on income can only be disclosed as required for program implementation and outreach efforts. The project will initially run for 3 years, with possible extensions recommended in subsequent reports. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will collaborate with States for State Demonstration Grants under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The Data Match Demonstration Project aims to identify individuals eligible for medical assistance under the Social Security Act through ex parte determinations or other methods. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is authorized to appropriate necessary funds for grants under this project. Additionally, there is CMS funding available for outreach and enrollment projects. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is appropriated $100,000,000 for grants to States to improve outreach and enrollment in Medicare Savings Programs. Projects may involve partnerships with community groups, Veterans' Affairs, and Indian Health Service. Periodic reports to Congress on project progress and recommendations for extensions or law changes will be submitted. SEC. 8. NOTICES TO CERTAIN NEW MEDICARE BENEFICIARIES. (a) SSA Notice.--When the Commissioner of Social Security notifies individuals of their eligibility for Medicare benefits, they must also send a notice and application for Medicaid benefits to those likely to qualify. The notice includes information on how to apply and where to get more information.
(b) Including Information in Medicare & You Handbook.--The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to include this information in the annual Medicare & You Handbook. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must include information on Medicare Savings Programs and a toll-free number in the annual Medicare & You Handbook.
